intro: Acantholimon saxifragifolium, commonly known as the saxifrage-leaved thornweed, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the rocky and arid regions of the western United States. It is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves that are often arranged in a basal rosette, which helps it conserve water in its harsh environment. The plant produces small, white or pale blue flowers in late spring to early summer, typically in clusters at the ends of its stems. Its leaves are covered in fine, soft hairs that provide additional protection against desiccation. Acantholimon saxifragifolium is adapted to grow in well-drained soils and is often found in crevices or on slopes where moisture is limited.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acantholimon saxifragifolium is primarily native to the coastal regions of southern California and northern Baja California, Mexico. It thrives in rocky coastal bluffs and sandy soils along the Pacific coast. This plant is commonly found in areas with mild, wet winters and dry summers. It is well adapted to the harsh maritime climate and salt spray. Its distribution is limited to a narrow geographic range along the western coast of North America.

It is commonly found in regions with Mediterranean climates, where it thrives in well-drained conditions.
